I remember learning about the difference between major and minor in music class as a kid with the teacher saying that major sounds "happy" and minor sounds "sad"... But most of the sadder songs that I can think of are in major?

Two months ago I upgraded from a flip phone to a smart phone, irreversibly, and it has been a huge distraction for me in terms of media consumption. How do I discipline myself out of this and back to music production? I'm ashamed of myself.

set some boundaries. first, do you need the phone for anything during music production? if not, then put it in a drawer. if you do actually need certain things from it during music production, then you will have to get used to setting some hard rules about never opening certain apps. the trick to getting used to this is the morning. if you can stay completely out of those apps when you first wake up, it will be much much much easier to avoid them for the rest of the work day, at least until the work day is done

since the picture being painted is kind of distant and longing, where as the chord is very straightforward feeling. Though at the same time i understand your choice within the context of the piece and the time limit. curious if you have any tidbits

the first way it came to me was as it is. when i went to work out the details, i refined it to actually be F over Bb (on "there") was more shiny and exotic that way, and seemed cool because that would actually make it nearly exactly how it happened on "grey" at the same time in the first verse except a half step higher. so i thought that would be the right answer, but then upon run-through in wider context it instantly felt wrong, and it was immediately clear that the way i first had it was better so i switched it back. sometimes what seems to work up close just doesn't work in the real time flow of the song in wider context. that's why full run throughs (like from the beginning) are so important, and the only way to find out what's really gonna work

So, I'm really getting into composing (mainly in Ableton Live), and I've discovered that I naturally gravitate toward writing instrumental music. If I had to describe my music, I think I'd call it programmatic. I try to write vocal music sometimes, but I freeze up when it comes to writing the actual vocal melody. Now, this wouldn't be so weird, if I myself wasn't a vocalist. How can I spend so much time around vocal music, and yet not be able to write any myself? What the hell is wrong with me?

what might be helpful is to get the writing done outside of the program. just get some paper or text, and your favorite playable instrument. write what you want to write, then once you know fully how it goes then go into the program and start putting it together according to the road map. if this still doesn't work then i recommend spending some quality time with the words alone. open a text file or blank piece of paper and go bananas for a few months
what is a power chord

you know how a major chord has one note different from a minor chord .... well a 'power chord' is when you don't play that note at all. just the 1 and 5. probably has the most 'power' when it's played on guitar with some distortion, in low range with another octave on top. so low E, B, E. or G, D, G. used all the time in distorted guitar music because major/minor intervals start to crap out when the distortion comes on, and also don't work in the low range. 'power chords' seem most at home in a reasonably low range, around the low area of a guitar. not to be confused with 'power cord' which provides electricity for the chord

one weird weird thing i noticed, i was mixing hallelujah for way way too long and feeling trapped and down about it, listening to 'new rules' side-by-side with it and just wanting to die over it, (by the way this was just days before i found out the loudness war is officially over. so now we don't have to worry about that which is huge huge news, but this was right before i realized that) anyway, i had done all this work on the mix for hallelujah, and it's also just a really dense and layered textural arrangement, etc, and whatever, and then i was poking around for reference songs (such as new rules and several other songs done by other people) and was generally freaking out about how much clearer everyone else's songs sounded but (i'm getting to the point of this, hold on) here's the surprise: i accidentally opened up one of my jazz jam sessions (like anything you would hear on the 'jazz' section of this site) and i was shocked to find out that that recording sounded so much more clear, sounded like it was mixed much much better, but as we all know it is not even mixed at all. those are instrumental jams where i lay down each instrument in 1 crazy take, bounce it out and call it a day. and the point is, i found out that that mix (which was no mix) had a lot more punch and clarity than this hallelujah mix which i had so tenderly spent so many long days on. the lesson was , ...... if you use a million instruments it is a real challenge to mix it out of sounding like mud. even if it's very tenderly layered and arranged instruments, the point is, if there are many instruments, they will clog up the mid range, like that troublesome 100-300 range. but if you use only 3 or 4 instruments,  ..... it's just got automatic clarity. so that's something. so this works to my advantage now working under these crazy deadline schedules, because i simply don't have time to make as dense an arrangement, and it is therefore easier to mix. Another thing i learned, on the subject of working faster, is, ... work faster. you gravitate toward what matters. and it is so easy to lose your mind if you listen to that damn thing for too long. you'll just lose your mind ...... another way to get tips is watching a billion mixing tutorials and tips videos until you realize they are all starting to contradict each other, and then you forget it and do what you want

Loving the new song. Probably one of my favorite songs of yours. I love the fact that you completed it in just two weeks and there's nothing I would change about the song, but what about you? If you had just a few days more to work on it, what would you have added/improved?

the mix didn't get the same level of attention as it did in the previous songs. there's probably too much of a general bulge around 200hz. to fix that you just have to crawl thru every instrument and figure out what to cut, and when. actually on the last 2 songs i went through the vocal and made very specific eq cuts custom to each word. it made a big difference especially for the car, because the car system is very volatile and sensitive. i didn't have time to do any of that. but, i did do what's absolutely necessary. in fact, when you have limited time, sometimes you resort to arrangement changes if something is not working. for example, the "not gonna happen" section was muddy and lumpy as hell, and normally i probably would have gone crazy cutting frequencies from vocals, background vocals, instruments, really just slaved over it. but instead i went back in and just added some drums, made some quicker fixes which might have had more impact. the important thing is, if you stay working on it too long, self doubt starts to set in

oh, now i get it. i come here and start talking to myself. forgetting to communicate. just thinking to self. forget to cut the thread until i realize how long it's gone. first i thought it needed to keep going because i hadn't made my 'point' yet. there's not a special point. it's just that if you keep thinking what you mean more meaning will be there and at the end there will be a wide horizon of truth and you look out at it and see something at some point that feels like 'it'. it can be cut off at any point. you realized that. but then you figured, well, if it can stop now, it can also continue. then i'll Really have some points!.. nah. it's just a window of insanity. insanity can carry meaning. wait, what's insanity? you think of it as disjointed from reality. rambling, sprawling, the focus tumbling forward and out and everywhere. it's inevitable that it catches on something important if you can still see that through the mess.  messy. messy? it's messy without focus. no filler allowed. what is the filler? how do i know which words are the fluff? the fluff diverts the focus. what is the focus? how do you know? you don't know when you do this. you're just thinking. you're just thinking. you're just thinking. you're just thinking. oh no. i didn't come here to do this. i came here to be focused. focus. use your 10. not your 2. this is the lab. yes. it's the lab. you can do anything in the lab. but you have to have a plan. the plan can be to have no plan. but that needs to be a choice. not your always. what you need is to distill the meaning. add fun, stir, enjoy. but don't waste time.

No such thing as an objective truth--- or at least there is as much objectivity in our universe as there is subjectivity--- Our realities are bounded by our sensory abilities and as everything in the universe is defined by the laws of cause and effect, we can assume that for all things and non-things (and things in-between things and non-things), a set path of event-to-events is in place as far as our perception of reality allows. I.e. if the exact circumstances that caused the creation of our universe were to reoccur in the exact same way, then every following time-related outcome would be identical. hi Bill, i have problems with singing high notes. right now lowest i can go is C#2 and highest i can go succesfully is C4. i want to sing above that but after C4 i feel like i'm straining my voice.

there's a weird and cool technique you can do. actually there's 2. one is keep your head pointing straight forward. sometimes you think you want to sing the note up. you don't need to do that. sing it straight across even if it's high. but the other really crazy trick, this is a psychological trick, pretend you are singing down to the note. pretend it's not the highest note you can sing. pretend it's a low note and sing down to the note. like pretend you can sing way higher and sing down to it. here's another trick, this one comes from tony robbins, just close your eyes and imagine yourself singing the note clearly and beautifully. just visualize it happening, 10 times in a row. now try it. these are all interesting tricks. but don't forget to warm up before doing high notes and don't push hard, and if it hurts don't do it

when you are writing a new song, how do youkeep track of lyrics and form? i know you record all the audio but forlike doing run through and building each section do you write anythingdown, or just listen back to what you played/sang to memorizeit?

i used to writethe chart on staff paper but i no longer use any paper. i use a textfile and audio recordings. the lyrics are written in the text, andnext to each line (maybe every 2 lines or every 4 lines) there is thefile name of the audio reference. when the song is done you mightoften see a file name at the top of the page for a full run thru. thenoften when starting the arrangement, i will whip up a "studio chart"(really just chords) based on the run-thru, and put it on paper justto have something on the stand to look at in the empty beginningstages of the arrangement. but pretty soon as things get filled in iwouldn't need it anymore because it's all in there. and then whendoing vocals i may type up a lyric cheat sheet. sometimes i mayreference the demo run-thru if i want to confirm what the exact melodywas

i failed on the 'i'm sad' video. i worked non-stop and it was 24-hours late. i lied on the website date and it didn't matter because i had no viewers. my point is this was day 2 of what became a long continuous schedule where i never missed again

so i recently had a breakthrough in which i realized that if i post to a public space (that people pay attention to) a deadline, it's so much more real because immediately there are people expecting something of me. even if nobody really cares if i release it on that day or not i still freak out and have to get it done by that time. are you using a similar motivation with sept. 4th and the questions page? i feel like on a large enough scale it could become terrifying and overwhelming but with what i have now it works great
